title: Section C
passagesOne: Questions 46 to 50 are based on the following passage.

questionsOne.Statement: What does the passage say about open educational resources?

Options.text: They contribute to teaching as much as to learning.
They don't profit as much as traditional textbooks do.
They can't connect professors and students as textbooks do.
They compete fiercely for customers with textbook producers.

questionsOne.Statement: What is the main cause of the publishers' losses?

Options.text: Failure to meet student need.
Industry restructuring.
Emergence of e-books.
Falling sales.

questionsOne.Statement: What does the textbook industry need to do?

Options.text: Reform its structures.
Cut its retail prices.
Find replacements for printed textbooks.
Change its business strategy periodically.

questionsOne.Statement: What are students expected to do in the learning process?

Options.text: Think carefully before answering each question.
Ask questions based on their own understanding.
Answer questions using their personal experience.
Give answers showing their respective personality.

questionsOne.Statement: What do experts say about students using textbooks?

Options.text: They can digitalize the prints easily.
They can learn in an interactive way.
They can purchase customized versions.
They can adapt the material themselves.

passagesTwo: Questions 51 to 55 are based on the following passage.

questionsTwo.Statement: What is the distinctive feature of a sea slug?

Options.text: It looks like both a plant and an animal.
It converts some sea animals into plants.
It lives half on animals and half on plants.
It gets energy from both food and sunlight.

questionsTwo.Statement: What enables the sea slug to live like a plant?

Options.text: The genes it captures from the sea plant algae.
The mechanism by which it conserves energy.
The nutrients it hijacks from other species.
The green pigment it inherits from its ancestors.

questionsTwo.Statement: What does the author say about baby sea slugs?

Options.text: They can live without sunlight for a long time.
They can absorb sunlight right after their birth.
They can survive without algae for quite some time.
They can produce chlorophyll on their own.

questionsTwo.Statement: What does Sidney Pierce say about genes from an alga?

Options.text: They are stolen from animals like the sea slug.
They can't function unless exposed to sunlight.
They don't usually function inside animal cells.
They can readily be converted to sea slug genes.

questionsTwo.Statement: What do we learn about sea slugs from the passage?

Options.text: They behave the way most plant species do.
They can survive for months without eating.
They will turn into plants when they mature.
They will starve to death without sunlight.
